newsitem.title: USA: U.S. MUNICIPAL FOCUS - up about 1/4 after data.
newsitem.headline: U.S. MUNICIPAL FOCUS - up about 1/4 after data.

text.p: U.S. municipal bond prices rose about 1/4 point Thursday morning after the August durable goods report dropped much more than expected, traders said.
The U.S. Commerce Department said durable goods orders fell 3.1 percent last month. Economists surveyed by Reuters had forecast the figure would show only a 0.1 percent decline.
Analysts said the figure might lend credence to the idea that the economy is slowing on its own, supporting the Federal Reserve's decision Tuesday not to raise interest rates.
The Treasury market also registered its approval of the weak data.
The long bond jumped more than 1/2 point following the number, moving the yield to 6.89 percent.
Among actively traded municipal bonds, yields on Metropolitan Pier and Exposition Authority, Ill., AMBAC 5-1/4s of 2027 were down five basis points to 5.83 percent.
Texas Turnpike Authority FGIC 5-1/4s of 2023 were down six basis points to 5.70 percent.
But some market participants said they were leery of rallying off of one number.
"We're peeking through the 6.90 level, which seems to be very uncomfortable every time we get there," said Richard Visconti, head of muni trading at W.R. Lazard & Co.
Visconti said the market will need to see a chain of several more market-friendly numbers if it hopes to maintain these levels.

Debt futures also rose off the durable goods number. The December municipal contract was up 18/32 to 114-16/32, and the December T-bond was up the same amount to 109-25/32. That left the MOB spread unchanged from Wednesday's close at 151 ticks.
On the new issue calendar, Lehman Brothers said it tentatively priced $54 million California Housing Finance Agency bonds at a top yield of 6.20 percent in 2022.
Morgan Stanley & Co tentatively priced $44.9 million New York City Educational Construction Fund bonds at a top yield of 5.78 percent in 2026.
Fort Worth, Texas, plans Thursday's largest negotiated deal, an $87.2 million general obligation issue through senior manager Merrill Lynch & Co.
Florida said it will sell the week's largest new issue Thursday, a $250 million competitive Board of Education issue at 1100 EDT.
